SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ........................................... Henry LACHMUTH

2. Your address ........................................... St. Gregory, Sask.

3. Date ........................................... May 15 - 1903

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Minneapolis, Minn USA

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Emil Lachmuth Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) May 10 - 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

   With my Parents lived at Mound Minn U.S.A.
   Lived there on a farm from 1894 to 1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). I was 15 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   It was that my Parents sold their home in Minneapolis, Minn U.S.A. To make a home for children namely two Brothers Paul & Emil and two Sisters Martha & Anna by a homestead for us Boys and it was a good move although a tough time we had in our first two Years of driving about 100 miles of no Roads from Rosther South Rail Road at that time.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    We got first Information through the Catholic Settlement Agent which was formed by the Benedictine Fathers and some prominent men of St. Cloud or Better of day men of Minnesota they made some Agreement with the Government to start a Colony of Catholic settlers with about 1200 families in 1903 and in 1905 they settled with about 80% Catholic folks more was called to about 80% Catholic folks more

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Henry Lachmuth
2. Your address: 304 Main Street, St. Gregor, Sask.
3. Date: May 15, 1903
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Germany
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Emil Lachmuth
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 15, 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Germany
   - Austria
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
   - I was in my teens
9. What was your occupation for coming West?
   - To make a living
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
    - Through the Government Information Office
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Our neighbors and many folks in our community didn't think we made a foolish move to immigrate to a country like Canada. They said it was a country for drifter's and thieves.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

We traveled by Soo Line Road to Moose Jaw and then by C.P.R. at that time via Regina to Rosther.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

From Rosther we went to Amahkine. It was about 100 miles and made 18 trips in the first two years with horse teams. We rode on the road the first trip along with two weeks making cordwood or canoe and sloughs until we lost all horses and had to pay off.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We met Indians many times in the first two years. They trapped and some small tribes roamed over our homestead over summer the first year and often a bunch of about 50 or 60 traveled through from Nick Mountain Reserve to Duck Lake for their annual treaty money and then away back to Nick Mtn. The world kept of here and there trapping they travel by some house or lodgings or dogs.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We arrived in Rosther May 10th and Mother & Young Sister and Brother stayed in a immigrant house the Catholic Settlement for newcomers to stay a few weeks.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Until we were able to get back to Amahkine. See 52 - Amahkine 18 - Aug. 20 on a homestead.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No place back at Amahkine and our children all farm at Amahkine. Yet only 3 of my daughters live with a Port St John B.C. on the Alaska Highway. I am at St. Joseph since 2 years retired.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

We farmed at Round Mine until 1903 since then we are here at Amahkine and had to make a little money by trapping and working on railroad construction until it was finished to Humboldt.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We often wrote to some of our relatives in the States but mail was carried only once until a few years ago.

Small stores got started for a post office about a month from Roeten.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

We got married in 1908 to Neil from St. Agatha Minn.

We got married at Amahkum.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes, they came a few times to Canada later. They moved here because the country was better settled and R.R. and roads were fairly built mostly after 1907, about four families from St. Boniface Minn. and still are here.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

One brother & wife came in 1907 to Amahkum and still live there.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I have been here all along from where we all these towns are before we had any rail road over and nothing settle from Modena to the Blackfoot river used to follow the old telegraph line from Modena to Bruneau, follow old ox trail as they called the North Trail to Roeten past Mount Carmel and all these trails were built since we came here. Saskatoon was just a little town and in 1907 the Rail Road Bridge a soddy was reached and cut off the foundation and it Roeten or P.Q. so many staged around Saskatoon.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Not very far only in our Colony or to get seed grown over Lake Louise to Red Springs or what it's called. To-day and got some lumber from Beaver and at Stone Lake.

Myself 4 day and 1/2 weeks distance from Beaver and at Nipawin Lake
25. When was the first car used in the community?
For 1915 a model T Ford bought by my Brother Paul.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
I bought my Ford in 1916 - and had about 6 or 7 since.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
We had a General Store at Amiskwac since 1907 and then Humboldt was our main place the town grew since.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
Humboldt got to be a R.R. Division point and Humboldt grew fast and got to be a good place to shop and is still a good business place.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
Not very often in the early day until towns grew up by getting Grain Elevator & Creamery bought.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
After Car Roads got made about 1925 or so it is the main shopping day now.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since then.
About 1925 people purchased clothing stores and some Furniture but Food is mostly bought at Home.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
Our Phone came in 1915 though here around Humboldt and nearly all Farmers have it today.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
We tried it out and even with my Hardship in the first 8 or 10 years where just kept going on until most of us where broke and had not money to move anywhere else so we had to stay and it turned out good since and our family seemed have prospered since and I believe we have a good place at our

Handwritten answers:

- The first car was used in the community in 1915.
- The first car bought was a Ford.
- The trading center was in the town of Regina.
- The trading center continued to be used until 1925.
- People started going to town regularly around 1920.
- Articles bought included clothing, shoes, and household goods.
- The first telephone was installed in 1915.
- The decision to stay permanently was made after trying it out.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not very many but a lot moved in especially during the dried out period of the Southern Port of Saskatchewan we was lucky to get always enough rain up here & much say we always had.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have held a few offices like School Trustee and Council in St Peter Municipality also made many Concrete Actions about 200 in several Munic also 5 large Culverts for the Department of Highway have been doing same from 1918 - 1947

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My Brother Paul Lashnuth had the First Threshing Steel Outfit in 1907 and the First Corn Truck and later a Wil Pull for Breaking Beach Land

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I have a few will try and gather them away day and more it is just so good and would like to get to see a smile up of 50 years of progress. We come once in Humboldt gathering some of this for a book.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have 3 children living at Amiski 2 at the Beaver 3 in B.C. Dad St John one in the Car Business in Humboldt.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I think we have nearly as much every convenience as alot of Old County good Roads, Power Lines Telephone and good Soil and good Schools & Churches and a lot of Recreation like Shows, Curling Rinks and Hockey and good Fishing in the North.
